newsitem.title: AUSTRALIA: RTRS - Australia govt sees Telstra vote within weeks.
newsitem.headline: RTRS - Australia govt sees Telstra vote within weeks.

text.p: Australian Communications Minister Richard Alston said on Monday he expected the Senate to vote in a matter of weeks on legislation aimed at partially selling telecommunications giant Telstra Corp.
"Yes, yes we're in the middle of the second reading debate now and we would expect that the vote will take place in a matter of weeks," Alston told reporters.

Independent Senator Brian Harradine and fellow Independent Mal Colston hold the key to the one-third sale of Telstra as the government requires two extra votes to pass legislation in the Senate. All other non-governmnet senators oppose the plan.

Alston said the government were still discussing Harradine's proposal to sell redeemable preference shares in Telstra Corp as an alternative to the government's planned one-third sale of the telecoms carrier.
"We've been having ongoing discussions with him (Harradine) and those discussions will probably continue for some time yet," Alston said.
Preference shares are assets part-way between equity and debt and their dividends are normally fixed.
If the company is wound up, the holder has preference over ordinary shareholders and redeemable preference shares can be redeemed for value, under specified conditions.
The government plans to raise A$8 billion from the one-third sale of Telstra with A$1 billion of that earmarked for its environmental upgrade programme.
